sentences.sentence: History would suggest that Canadian bank stocks are cheaper than they appear.

Accurately forecasting earnings becomes increasingly challenging during credit cycles like the current COVID downturn, which has implications for bank stocks and how investors should interpret price-to-earnings multiples.

Historically, during periods of rising loan losses, analysts have tended to underestimate the severity of the cycle causing banks to miss estimates and placing downward pressure on bank stocks.Similarly, analysts also historically underestimate the strength of the recovery as the credit cycle turns, causing banks to beat estimates and bank stocks to rally.
This is relevant because the Canadian banks have very clearly entered the recovery stage of the credit cycle.
That means, if history is a guide, analyst estimates for the next two years are likely understated.
Possibly by a lot.The chart below highlights how difficult it is for analysts to accurately estimate earnings during credit downturns and recoveries.

This is significant for Canadian bank investors because as the recovery advances, analyst estimates for the next two years could be understated by between five per cent and 10 per cent per year, meaning the "real" P/Es for the Canadian banks are lower than they appear.

If correct it would mean the market is currently underestimating the potential upside to Canadian bank shares.When the banks reported Q4 2020 earnings, it was clear the worst of the cycle was behind them.
When the banks reported Q1 2021 results, it was clear the recovery had begun.

The banks begin reporting Q2 on May 26 and investors should not be surprised if the banks all exceed analyst expectations and forecast earnings rise.High-flying loonie's 'good' dilemma for investors: Ride the streak or shop abroad?

Toronto the Boring is now North America's top financial centre, next to New York(https://financialpost.com/news/economy/who-knew-toronto-the-boring-is-now-north-americas-top-financial-centre-next-to-new-york)Wealthsimple valuation should be a wake-up call for big banks and traditional money managers(https://financialpost.com/investing/wealthsimple-valuation-should-be-a-wake-up-call-for-big-banks-and-traditional-money-managers)In energy-reliant Canada, banks and investors face dilemma in meeting emissions target(https://financialpost.com/fp-finance/banking/in-energy-reliant-canada-banks-and-investors-face-dilemma-in-meeting-emissions-target-3)If history repeats, the analysts are likely underestimating the recovery and upward earnings revisions could be as much as 10 per cent, meaning the "real" price-to-earnings ratios would be between 0.5x and 1.0x lower than they appear providing further support for Canadian bank investors in 2021.Rob Wessel is Managing Partner of Hamilton ETFs and is a frequent commentator on the Canadian banks and global financials.
Additional insights on the sector can be found atwww.hamiltonetfs.com(http://s.bl-1.com/h/dhxJWQ6F?url=http://www.hamiltonetfs.com).

Accurately forecasting earnings becomes increasingly challenging during credit cycles like the current COVID downturn, which has implications for bank stocks and how investors should interpret price-to-earnings multiples. Historically, during periods of rising loan losses, analysts have tended to underestimate the severity of the cycle causing banks to miss estimates and placing downward pressure on bank stocks.Similarly, analysts also historically underestimate the strength of the recovery as the credit cycle turns, causing banks to beat estimates and bank stocks to rally. This is relevant because the Canadian banks have very clearly entered the recovery stage of the credit cycle. That means, if history is a guide, analyst estimates for the next two years are likely understated. Possibly by a lot.The chart below highlights how difficult it is for analysts to accurately estimate earnings during credit downturns and recoveries. This is significant for Canadian bank investors because as the recovery advances, analyst estimates for the next two years could be understated by between five per cent and 10 per cent per year, meaning the "real" P/Es for the Canadian banks are lower than they appear.
